Posts.Content: Unfortunately everyone here recounting emotion-laden laundry lists of terrible things that their loved ones went through is not going to inure you to the unpleasantness.  If anything I think it will overwhelm you.  Furthermore, many of the terrible experiences others had may not be applicable to your mother's situation.  Please share your concerns with hospice.  They will be able to answer your questions and provide you with some helpful literature.  Please also speak with them regarding your mother's pain.  She shouldn't have to be in pain. Keep us posted as you can.
Posts.Title: Gruesome Details. Sorry to ask but Please help!

Posts.Content: I'm so sorry to hear about your diagnosis.  Obviously this is not the news for which you were hoping.  MD Anderson is an excellent choice -- the only NCI-rated Comprehensive Cancer Center in Texas.  I hope you can get into see someone at MD Anderson very soon.  You'll feel better when you have a plan of action.  Keep us posted as you can.  Sending good thoughts your way.
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: I realize your family history gives you cause for concern, but try to stay calm.  It may not be anything at all.  I've been asked to come back in for additional pix (and ultrasounds) on several occasions and everything has always turned out ok.  Sometimes the tech simply doesn't get a good shot and needs to take another picture.  (Hey, they're human.) I have had one lump removed (it was benign) and another aspirated (also benign).  Not everything you can feel is cancer.  It may well just be a cyst.  The important thing is that you've taken action to get to the bottom of this.  Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Thinking of you -- I know you have the needle biopsy today.  I hope the procedure goes smoothly and that you get your results quickly.  Hang in there!
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: If it makes you feel any better, I have gone through this several times before -- make that four, to be precise.  You've heard of the Queen of Hearts?  Well, apparently I am the Queen of Lumps, all benign.  It's always hair raising.  If your last ultra was 6 weeks ago, it's unlikely a malignant tumor could come on so quickly that you're having symptoms, in both breasts no less.  About going for the ultra and skipping the mammo -- my insurance will not cover ultra without doing mammo first to prove the need.  It's so stupid because I have very dense breast tissue and the mammo is useless -- but they make me get one every time.
Posts.Title: Freaking out!
